content.webTitle: Ecstasy as Juno reaches Jupiter, but now the hard work starts

fields.headline: Ecstasy as Juno reaches Jupiter, but now the hard work starts
fields.bodyText: It was a moment of immense jubilation as a voice announced: “Juno, welcome to Jupiter.” For five years, Nasa’s Juno spacecraft has been travelling through space, covering 1.8bn miles (2.8bn km) to reach the gas giant in a mission that will shed light on one of the most mysterious planets in the solar system. Costing $1.1bn (£840m), the mission has attracted the eyes of the world, with a live video link to the operations centre providing a fly-on-the-wall scene as Juno neared its goal. Finally, at 0318 GMT on Tuesday, scientists pulled off a nail-biting manoeuvre in which the spacecraft slowed down, amid Jupiter’s dust rings and radiation belt, so that it could be pulled into orbit around the planet. “Juno sang, and it was a song of perfection,” said project manager Rick Nybakken in a press conference following the triumph. Others too, seemed delighted and relieved. “The risks that were overcome, it’s amazing” said Diane Brown, Juno’s project manager from Nasa’s jet propulsion laboratory. “The more you know about the mission the more you know about how tricky it was. To know we can go to bed tonight not worrying about what is going to happen tomorrow, is just amazing.” Scott Bolton, the principal investigator of the Juno mission, was similarly euphoric: “You’re the best team ever!” he told his colleagues. “We just did the hardest thing Nasa has ever done.” The spacecraft itself sent a message of thanks via Twitter. But as Nasa’s team celebrated, Juno’s task has just begun. The size of a basketball court, the spacecraft will spend 20 months peering beneath the clouds of Jupiter, helping scientists to unpick the puzzles of the gas giant – such as whether the planet’s core is solid and why its great red spot appears to be shrinking. “In a couple of days, we will turn these science instruments back on and we will start gathering data,” Bolton told the Guardian. But with the spacecraft currently in a 53-day orbit, the spacecraft is not scheduled to swing close to Jupiter until the end of August. That event, says Bolton, will provide data on everything from the planet’s gravity to its magnetic field, as well as offering the first look at its deep atmosphere. It will also shed light on another conundrum: the conditions Juno is facing. “We still don’t have a real understanding of what the environment was that we just flew through,” said Bolton. “We know we just survived it. “The very first view with these instruments from a unique perspective, will come at the end of August.” After a second 53-day orbit, the team will slow down the spacecraft by firing its engines, putting it in a 14-day orbit around Jupiter in mid-October. “Once we do that every other Wednesday we will fly very very close to Jupiter and we will begin mapping it, which is what the primary goals are about,” said Bolton. With Juno a mere 3,000 miles from Jupiter at its closest (by comparison, the moon orbits roughly 238,800 miles from Earth), the spacecraft is expected to encounter astonishingly harsh conditions, including strong radiation and an extremely high magnetic field, as well as the possibility of dust and, potentially, meteorites – all of which could cause havoc for spacecraft. “At the speeds we are travelling, which are about 165,000 miles an hour, if a pebble hits you, it is a much more serious issue,” said Bolton. “[Juno] is the fastest racecar in the world, ever.” In an attempt to safeguard Juno, the spacecraft features titanium and tantalum shielding as well as other precautions. But it remains to be seen if they are enough. “We couldn’t really test it completely for those environments because we couldn’t create a laboratory that is Jupiter,” said Bolton. For now, he says, they will simply have to watch and wait. “We can’t afford false confidence that everything is OK because we have not gone through [the environment] with our eyes and ears open,” he added. “There will be continued nail biting for the next couple of passes until we can establish with our sensors what is it that we are really going though.” The success of putting Juno into orbit, however, bodes well for the mission, he says. “The thing I am most excited about is we are finally going to see inside Jupiter,” said Bolton. “I am pretty confident that, because we did so well [on Monday] night, that we will at least get a couple of looks deep into Jupiter to see what it is like, even if the environment is really, really bad.” Like Brown, Bolton could be forgiven for looking forward to a good night’s rest, but with the mission in many ways just beginning that seems unlikely. “I was incredibly tired, because I haven’t slept much over the last few days,” he said. “Now I am excited and I can’t sleep!”
